title: Mount Buller (Victoria)
text:
Mount Buller is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in the <a href="Victorian%20Alps">Victorian Alps</a> of the <a href="Great%20Dividing%20Range">Great Dividing Range</a>, located in the <a href="Australia">Australia</a>n state of <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a>. It has an elevation of ,
Toponym.
The British explorer and surveyor Major <a href="Sir%20Thomas%20Livingstone%20Mitchell">Sir Thomas Livingstone Mitchell</a> named the mountain after an acquaintance in the <a href="Colonial%20Office">Colonial Office</a>, <a href="Charles%20Buller">Charles Buller</a>. The Aboriginal name for the mountain is "Bulla Bulla" meaning "good".
Geography.
The summit of Buller can be approached by vehicle via the village coupled with a short 500 metre (1600 foot) walk. It is also possible to climb the peak from <a href="Delatite%20River">Delatite River</a> level along the Klingsporn walking track. The Klingsporn track was originally a bridle trail used by stockmen taking their cattle up to high ground during the summer months. 
The walk begins at Merimbah and is a walk on a well defined track. Mclaughlin Spur offers good views to the summit fire tower and the rocky outcrops that must be traversed. At the summit there is a stone distance dial and a fire tower that is manned during the summer months.
Resort.
The <a href="Mount%20Buller%20Alpine%20Resort">Mount Buller Alpine Resort</a> is a popular destination in winter for skiers and snowboarders of all abilities who wish to attend for the day. With it only being a 3 hour drive, it is the nearest major downhill ski resort to <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>. In the warmer months, it provides a base for day visitors and hikers in the Victorian Alps.
